title: 112_hr3829
content: The "Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012" or the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires a criminal background check for child care providers under the Child Care and Development Block Grant Act of 1990. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates a criminal background check for child care staff and providers, including a search of the National Sex Offender Registry. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires background checks for child care staff, including searches of national and state criminal registries and abuse databases. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates background checks for child care providers, including searches of state-based abuse and neglect registries, databases, and FBI fingerprint checks. Providers found ineligible will not receive funding under this act. Child care providers must undergo background checks, including FBI fingerprint checks, to be eligible for funding under the "CARE for Kids Act of 2012." Ineligibility is determined by adult felony convictions related to child abuse, spousal abuse, or crimes against children. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" requires child care providers to undergo background checks, including FBI fingerprint checks. Ineligibility is based on adult felony convictions for child abuse, spousal abuse, crimes against children, violent crimes, and drug offenses within 5 years prior to submission. The "CARE for Kids Act of 2012" mandates background checks for child care providers, including FBI fingerprint checks. Ineligibility is determined by adult felony convictions for specific offenses within 5 years prior to the background check submission. Child care providers must request a State and national criminal background check through the designated State agency. Child care providers must request a State and national criminal background check through the designated State agency before the implementation of the Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. Child care providers must undergo criminal background checks before implementing the Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. This includes regular checks every 5 years for staff members, family providers, and adults involved in child care. Child care providers, staff members, family providers, and adults involved in child care must undergo criminal background checks every 5 years as per the Child Care Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. Child care staff, family providers, and adults in child care must undergo a State and national criminal background check every 5 years. Only one request is needed for each individual residing in a private residence. Not more than 1 request for a State and national criminal background check is required for child care staff, family child care providers, or adults residing in the provider's private residence every 5 years. Results must be provided within 10 business days of the request being made to the appropriate State agency. Upon request, a State agency must provide the results of a criminal background check within 10 business days to individuals or entities requesting it. Additionally, the State shall give a copy of the background check to child care providers or individuals subject to the check. A State must provide a copy of the criminal background check to child care providers or individuals subject to the check upon request. The State is required to ensure the accuracy and completeness of the information in the background check by obtaining dispositions of arrests that occurred more than 1 year prior to the request date. The background check must be accurate and complete by obtaining arrest dispositions, correcting inaccurate information, completing incomplete entries, and taking steps to improve accuracy. Appeals must be made within 30 days. The background check process must be accurate and complete, including obtaining arrest dispositions and correcting any inaccuracies. Appeals can be made within 30 days to the designated State agency. Appeals can be made within 30 days to the appropriate State agency designated by the State for a final ruling on the eligibility or ineligibility of the individual, along with specific findings and potential changes to the individual's criminal record. The State agency must provide specific findings and make changes to the individual's criminal record if inaccurate or incomplete, and report these changes to the individual. A fee may be collected for a criminal background check from child care providers or families to cover the costs. To cover the costs of required criminal background checks, a State may collect a fee not exceeding $36 per check from child care providers or family child care providers. States must implement these requirements within 3 years. The Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012 limits the fee for required criminal background checks to $36. States must comply with these requirements within 3 years, with a possible 2-year extension granted for good faith efforts. The Secretary may grant a 2-year extension to a State making a good faith effort to comply with the requirements of the Childcare Accountability and Responsibility Act of 2012. Definitions include 'adult' as a person over 18 years old and 'child care provider' as a center-based or group home provider of child care services for compensation. A child care provider is a center-based or group home provider of child care services for compensation, not related to all children in their care, and licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. A child care staff member is an individual who provides child care services. The term 'child care staff member' refers to an individual who provides child care services for compensation on a regular basis, regardless of whether they work for a child care provider or a family child care provider. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for fewer than. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for fewer than 24 hours per day, as the sole caregiver, in a private residence, and is licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. The term 'family child care provider' refers to an individual who provides child care services for children and is licensed, regulated, or registered under State law. Authorization of appropriations is provided for conducting criminal background checks.
